query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 «Vexilla regis prodeunt inferni 2 verso di noi; però dinanzi mira», 3 disse ’l maestro mio, «se tu ’l discerni».
query.result: 1 The banners of the king of hell proceed 2 towards us; therefore look ahead, 3 said my master, “if you discern them.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
4 Come quando una grossa nebbia spira, 5 o quando l’emisperio nostro annotta, 6 par di lungi un molin che ’l vento gira,
7 veder mi parve un tal dificio allotta; 8 poi per lo vento mi ristrinsi retro 9 al duca mio, ché non lì era altra grotta.
query.result:
4 As when a thick mist breathes, 5 or when our hemisphere darkens, 6 it seems from afar a mill that the wind turns,
7 to see me seemed such a building then; 8 then by the wind I drew myself back 9 to my leader, because there was no other cave there.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
10 Già era, e con paura il metto in metro, 11 là dove l’ombre tutte eran coperte, 12 e trasparien come festuca in vetro.
query.result: 10 It already was, and with fear I put it into verse, 11 where all the shades were covered, 12 and appeared as rushes in glass.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
13 Altre sono a giacere; altre stanno erte, 14 quella col capo e quella con le piante; 15 altra, com’ arco, il volto a’ piè rinverte.

Please translate each line literally into English.
16 Quando noi fummo fatti tanto avante, 17 ch’al mio maestro piacque di mostrarmi 18 la creatura ch’ebbe il bel sembiante,
19 d’innanzi mi si tolse e fé restarmi, 20 «Ecco Dite», dicendo, «ed ecco il loco 21 ove convien che di fortezza t’armi».
query.result:
16 When we had gone so far ahead, 17 that to my master it pleased to show to me 18 the creature who had the beautiful appearance,
19 before me he removed himself and made me remain, 20 “Behold Dis,” saying, “and behold the place 21 where it is necessary that with strength you arm yourself.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Com’ io divenni allor gelato e fioco, 23 nol dimandar, lettor, ch’i’ non lo scrivo, 24 però ch’ogne parlar sarebbe poco.
query.result: 22 As I became then frozen and pale, 23 do not ask it, reader, for I do not write it, 24 because every speech would be little.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 Io non mori’ e non rimasi vivo; 26 pensa oggimai per te, s’hai fior d’ingegno, 27 qual io divenni, d’uno e d’altro privo.

Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Lo ’mperador del doloroso regno 29 da mezzo ’l petto uscia fuor de la ghiaccia; 30 e più con un gigante io mi convegno,
31 che i giganti non fan con le sue braccia: 32 vedi oggimai quant’ esser dee quel tutto 33 ch’a così fatta parte si confaccia.
query.result:
28 The emperor of the painful kingdom 29 from the middle of the chest came forth from the ice; 30 and more with a giant I come together,
31 than giants do not make with their arms: 32 see now how much must be that whole 33 which is suited to so made a part.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 S’el fu sì bel com’ elli è ora brutto, 35 e contra ’l suo fattore alzò le ciglia, 36 ben dee da lui procedere ogne lutto.
query.result: 34 If he was so beautiful as he is now ugly, 35 and against his maker raised the eyebrows, 36 well must from him proceed every sorrow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 Oh quanto parve a me gran maraviglia 38 quand’ io vidi tre facce a la sua testa! 39 L’una dinanzi, e quella era vermiglia;
40 l’altr’ eran due, che s’aggiugnieno a questa 41 sovresso ’l mezzo di ciascuna spalla, 42 e sé giugnieno al loco de la cresta:
43 e la destra parea tra bianca e gialla; 44 la sinistra a vedere era tal, quali 45 vegnon di là onde ’l Nilo s’avvalla.

Please translate each line literally into English.
46 Sotto ciascuna uscivan due grand’ ali, 47 quanto si convenia a tanto uccello: 48 vele di mar non vid’ io mai cotali.
query.result: 46 Under each one came forth two great wings, 47 as much as was fitting for so great a bird: 48 sails of the sea I never saw such.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Non avean penne, ma di vispistrello 50 era lor modo; e quelle svolazzava, 51 sì che tre venti si movean da ello:
52 quindi Cocito tutto s’aggelava.
query.result:
49 They did not have feathers, but in the manner of a bat 50 was their way; and those flapped, 51 so that three winds moved from it:
52 therefore Cocitus all froze over.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
53 Con sei occhi piangëa, e per tre menti 54 gocciava ’l pianto e sanguinosa bava.
55 Da ogne bocca dirompea co’ denti 56 un peccatore, a guisa di maciulla, 57 sì che tre ne facea così dolenti.
query.result:
53 With six eyes it wept, and through three mouths 54 dripped the weeping and bloody saliva.
55 From each mouth burst forth with the teeth 56 a sinner, in the manner of a mangled thing, 57 so that three made them so sorrowful.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
58 A quel dinanzi il mordere era nulla 59 verso ’l graffiar, che talvolta la schiena 60 rimanea de la pelle tutta brulla.
query.result: 58 Before that, the biting was nothing 59 toward the scratching, which sometimes the back 60 remained of the skin all stripped.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 «Quell’ anima là sù c’ha maggior pena», 62 disse ’l maestro, «è Giuda Scarïotto, 63 che ’l capo ha dentro e fuor le gambe mena.
query.result: 61 “That soul up there who has the most pain,” 62 said the master, “is Judas Scariot, 63 who has the head inside and moves the legs outside.”

64 Of the other two who have the head down, 65 the one who hangs from the dark face is Brutus: 66 see how he writhes, and does not speak!;
67 and the other is Cassius, who appears so stout.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
68 Ma la notte risurge, e oramai 69 è da partir, ché tutto avem veduto».
70 Com’ a lui piacque, il collo li avvinghiai; 71 ed el prese di tempo e loco poste, 72 e quando l’ali fuoro aperte assai,
73 appigliò sé a le vellute coste; 74 di vello in vello giù discese poscia 75 tra ’l folto pelo e le gelate croste.
query.result:
68 But the night rises again, and now 69 it is time to depart, because we have seen everything.
70 As it pleased him, I clasped his neck; 71 and he put himself in time and place, 72 and when the wings were open enough,
73 he clung to the velvety sides; 74 from fleece to fleece he descended then 75 through the thick fur and the frozen crusts.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Quando noi fummo là dove la coscia 77 si volge, a punto in sul grosso de l’anche, 78 lo duca, con fatica e con angoscia,
79 volse la testa ov’ elli avea le zanche, 80 e aggrappossi al pel com’ om che sale, 81 sì che ’n inferno i’ credea tornar anche.
query.result:
76 When we were where the thigh 77 turns, at a point on the thickness of the hip, 78 the guide, with effort and with anguish,
79 turned the head where he had the legs, 80 and clung to the fur as a man who climbs, 81 so that I believed we were also returning to hell.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
82 «Attienti ben, ché per cotali scale», 83 disse ’l maestro, ansando com’ uom lasso, 84 «conviensi dipartir da tanto male».
query.result: 82 “Hold on well, because by such stairs,” 83 said the master, panting like a weary man, 84 “one must depart from so much evil.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
85 Poi uscì fuor per lo fóro d’un sasso 86 e puose me in su l’orlo a sedere; 87 appresso porse a me l’accorto passo.

query.result:
88 I raised my eyes and believed to see 89 Lucifer as I had left him, 90 and saw his legs held up;
91 and if I became then troubled, 92 let the large people think, who do not see 93 what is that point that I had passed.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 «Lèvati sù», disse ’l maestro, «in piede: 95 la via è lunga e ’l cammino è malvagio, 96 e già il sole a mezza terza riede».
query.result: 94 “Get up on your feet,” said the master, “standing: 95 the way is long and the path is evil, 96 and already the sun returns to the third hour.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
97 Non era camminata di palagio 98 là ’v’ eravam, ma natural burella 99 ch’avea mal suolo e di lume disagio.
query.result: 97 It was not a walk of a palace 98 where we were, but a natural ravine 99 which had bad ground and discomfort of light.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 «Prima ch’io de l’abisso mi divella, 101 maestro mio», diss’ io quando fui dritto, 102 «a trarmi d’erro un poco mi favella:
103 ov’ è la ghiaccia? e questi com’ è fitto 104 sì sottosopra? e come, in sì poc’ ora, 105 da sera a mane ha fatto il sol tragitto?».
query.result:
100 “Before I pull myself from the abyss, 101 my master,” I said when I was upright, 102 “to tell me a little to draw me from error:
103 where is the ice? and this how is fixed 104 so upside down? and how, in so little time, 105 from evening to morning has the sun made the journey?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Ed elli a me: «Tu imagini ancora 107 d’esser di là dal centro, ov’ io mi presi 108 al pel del vermo reo che ’l mondo fóra.
query.result: 106 And he to me: “You still imagine 107 to be beyond the center, where I seized 108 by the pelt of the guilty worm that bores the world.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Di là fosti cotanto quant’ io scesi; 110 quand’ io mi volsi, tu passasti ’l punto 111 al qual si traggon d’ogne parte i pesi.

Please translate each line literally into English.
112 E se’ or sotto l’emisperio giunto 113 ch’è contraposto a quel che la gran secca 114 coverchia, e sotto ’l cui colmo consunto
115 fu l’uom che nacque e visse sanza pecca; 116 tu haï i piedi in su picciola spera 117 che l’altra faccia fa de la Giudecca.
query.result:
112 And now you are under the hemisphere arrived 113 that is opposed to that which the great dryness 114 covers, and under whose summit consumed
115 was the man who was born and lived without sin; 116 you have your feet on a small sphere 117 that makes the other face of Judecca.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 Qui è da man, quando di là è sera; 119 e questi, che ne fé scala col pelo, 120 fitto è ancora sì come prim’ era.

Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Da questa parte cadde giù dal cielo; 122 e la terra, che pria di qua si sporse, 123 per paura di lui fé del mar velo,
124 e venne a l’emisperio nostro; e forse 125 per fuggir lui lasciò qui loco vòto 126 quella ch’appar di qua, e sù ricorse».
query.result:
121 From this side he fell down from heaven; 122 and the land, that before leaned over here, 123 for fear of him made a veil of the sea,
124 and came to our hemisphere; and perhaps 125 to flee him left here an empty place 126 that which appears from here, and went upwards.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 Luogo è là giù da Belzebù remoto 128 tanto quanto la tomba si distende, 129 che non per vista, ma per suono è noto
130 d’un ruscelletto che quivi discende 131 per la buca d’un sasso, ch’elli ha roso, 132 col corso ch’elli avvolge, e poco pende.
query.result:
127 Place is there down from Belzebub remote 128 as much as the tomb extends itself, 129 that not by sight, but by sound is known
130 of a small stream that there descends 131 through the hole of a stone, which it has eroded, 132 with the course that it surrounds, and little hangs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Lo duca e io per quel cammino ascoso 134 intrammo a ritornar nel chiaro mondo; 135 e sanza cura aver d’alcun riposo,
136 salimmo sù, el primo e io secondo, 137 tanto ch’i’ vidi de le cose belle 138 che porta ’l ciel, per un pertugio tondo.
query.result:
133 The guide and I through that hidden path 134 entered to return to the clear world; 135 and without having care for any rest,
136 we climbed up, he first and I second, 137 so much that I saw of the beautiful things 138 that the sky carries, through a round opening.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
139 E quindi uscimmo a riveder le stelle.
query.result: 139 And then we emerged to see the stars again.
